g.text: datasets are used in the study:
concentrations from 2013 to 2017 are measured by the Urban Air Quality Center in
China, operated by the Chinese Environmental Production Ministration (CEPM), at 367 monitoring stations
). Based on the hourly average O
values (MDA8) and maximum average 1-hour ozone values (MDA1) are calculated in the Shanghai area. The
concentrations from late-summer in 2013 to 2017 are further calcu-
lated. (2) The hourly photolysis rate of NO
]) is measured and analyzed at the Pudong monitoring site of
To make a comprehensive analysis of WPSH, four different meteorological data
sets are used in this study: (1) The hourly surface meteorological parameters at Shanghai Baoshan Climate
Observatory (including temperature, relative humidity, 10 m wind direction and wind speed) are measured and
analyzed. The measurements in this site are used for the international meteorological data exchange sponsored by
World Meteorological Organization (WMO). Thus these data can well depict the local meteorological characteris-
tics in Shanghai. (2) Surface temperature at 160 Chinese monitoring sites are obtained from the National Climate
Center of China. (3) The climate data of five WPSH indices (including area, intensity, ridge position, northern
boundary position and western ridge point index) are obtained from the National Climate Center of China. (4)
The large-scale weather conditions, such as general circulation are used the data from the National Center for
Environmental Prediction (NCEP) and National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) reanalysis data
data have a horizontal resolution of 2.5°
2.5°, including the geo-potential height, specific humidity and winds
data. In addition, the solar radiation data with a horizontal resolution of 1.875°
1.904° is also used in this article.
(MOZART-4; Model for Ozone and Related chemical Tracers, version-4) is used in this study. The detailed
model description is shown by Emmons
, and the detailed aerosol modules are shown by Tie
MOZART-4 model is a global chemical transport model. The model is designed to study the global distribu-
tions of tropospheric trace gases and aerosol particles. In this study, the horizontal resolution of the model is
0.7°, with 42 vertical levels. Advection of tracers is performed using the flux-formed semi-Lagrangian
. The deep convection scheme developed by Zhang and McFarlane
The model transport is driven by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) assimi-
. The meteorological data is interpolated to fit the model
horizontal resolution by using a bilinear interpolation method. The MOZART model with such configurations
has been successfully employed by Chang
to investigate the impact of El Niño event on regional air quality
of China. The MOZART-4 model is applied to calculate the contributions of individual processes to O
including the total diffusion (DIF), advection (ADV) and gas-phase chemistry (CHEM).
All data is available on-line and free of charge. NCEP Reanalysis data provided by the NOAA/OAR/ESRL PSD,
Boulder, Colorado, USA, from their Web site at
reanalysis data is available at the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts. The WPSH indices
(including area, intensity, ridge position, northern boundary position and western ridge point index) can be
obtained from the National Climate Center of China. The observational data of surface O
parameters (including temperature, relative humidity, 10 m wind direction and wind speed) can be obtained
variability in Shanghai, China: application of the WRF-Chem model.
. Effect of heavy haze and aerosol pollution on rice and wheat productions in China.
. Current and future ozone risks to global terrestrial biodiversity and ecosystem processes.
4. Tai, A. P. K. & Martin, M. V. Impacts of ozone air pollution and temperature extremes on crop yields: Spatial variability, adaptation
and implications for future food security.
. Severe Pollution in China Amplified by Atmospheric Moisture.
. Chemical characterization of air pollution in Eastern China and the Eastern United States.
7. Geng, F. H., Zhao, C. S., Tang, X., Lu, G. L. & Tie, X. Analysis of ozone and VOCs measured in Shanghai: a case study.
inter-annual oscillation during 2013 to 2015 in Shanghai, China.
in a mega City (Shanghai), China: Characteristics, causes, and interactions with precursors.
. Temporal-Spatial Characteristics and Impact Factors of Ozone Pollution in Shanghai.
Rethinking the Ozone Problem in Urban and Regional Air Pollution
12. Sillman, S. The use of NO
as indicators for ozone-NOx hydrocarbon sensitivity in urban locations.
